STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 17, 2024
Kathleen Nikesch
WELLSPRING LUTHERAN SERVICES KENTWOOD
1715 SUTHERLAND DR,
KENTWOOD, MI, 49508-3306
Re: License #: CB410201260
SI #: 2025SIC0000167
Dear Kathleen Nikesch:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000167
Special Investigation Intake Date: December 3, 2024
License #: CB410201260
Licensee Group Organization: Wellspring Lutheran Services
Licensee Designee: Jason Sroufe
Chief Administrator: Kathleen Nikesch
Agency Name: WELLSPRING LUTHERAN SERVICES
KENTWOOD
Agency Address: 1715 SUTHERLAND DR
KENTWOOD, MI 49508-3306
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 06/28/2026
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
12/4/2024 10:00 AM Email Special Investigation Initiation
12/5/2024 9:00 AM Documentation Other
12/5/2024 9:45 AM Video Conference Interview
12/5/2024 2:00 PM Phone Interview
12/5/2024 3:00 PM Phone Interview
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Compliance with the child protection law
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12214
Section • (1) An agency shall comply with the child protection law,
Description 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A staff member was made aware of concerns regarding a staff
member at another facility providing a nicotine vape to a youth
and did not report the concerns timely.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via video conference on
December 5, 2024. She stated Youth A is currently placed in a
residential facility. During a home visit on November 25, 2024,
with Youth A’s previous caregiver there were allegations disclosed
to Foster Care Worker (FCW) regarding concerns staff at the
residential facility have provided Youth A with nicotine vapes. In
addition, there were concerns Youth A was not provided PRN
medication. Complainant stated FCW did not report the concerns
until December 2, 2024.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC Supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on 12/5/2024. Last Wednesday FCW sent a text and
asked if she had time to discuss some concerns regarding Youth
A and the residential facility. When she arrived at the agency,
FCW stated Caregiver reported some concerns to her about the
residential facility. She stated Caregiver reported a staff member
had been providing Youth A with vapes. FC Supervisor stated
before proceeding with anything else, the concerns needed to be
called in to Centralized Intake (CI) that day. In addition, there was
a home visit with Youth A where some of the medications were
not provided by the residential facility. If further discussion needs
to occur, they can meet at a later date. FC Supervisor stated she
saw FCW write down in her notebook to call in the concerns. FCW
stated she would call in to CI when she got home that evening.
FC Supervisor reminded her that it needed to be called in that
day.
The agency was closed due to Thanksgiving. On Monday she
double checked her email to see if she had received a notification
from CI. FC Supervisor stated she always makes sure to check
her email for CI notification if any of her staff has anything that
needs to be reported to ensure it is reported as required. She
2

didn’t see an email from CI, so she followed up with FCW. FCW
apologized and informed her that she had forgotten. FC
Supervisor instructed her to call it in right away as it should have
been reported that same day, she was made aware of the
concerns. FC Supervisor sent FCW a reminder at the end of the
day on Monday because she hadn’t seen an email from
Centralized Intake. FC Supervisor said she instructed FCW to call
Centralized Intake 3 times. She stated FCW called it in on Monday
night. If FCW wouldn’t have made the call, she had planned on
calling herself. She wanted FCW to report because she had first-
hand knowledge of the concerns that were reported to her. FC
Supervisor stated mandated reporter training is part of the Child
Welfare Training Institute (CWTI). It is also part of the agency’s
Relias training. In addition, there are reminders by the
supervisors.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
December 5, 2024. She stated she is the assigned FCW for
Youth A who is currently placed at a residential facility. She
conducted a home visit with Youth B who is Youth A’s sibling on
November 25, 2024. During the home visit, Caregiver reported a
staff member at the residential facility was providing youth,
including Youth A, with vapes. In addition, there were concerns
reported by Caregiver that Youth A had been home the previous
weekend and was not provided with some of her medication.
There had also been a psychiatry appointment, and the residential
facility did not invite or include Caregiver.
FCW stated she took notes during the visit and when she left the
home visit, she had another appointment involving another case in
Kalamazoo which was an hour and a half away. FCW
acknowledged she should have contacted FC Supervisor
immediately once the concerns had been reported to her, but she
got caught up in her other work and did not follow up right away.
FCW clarified that she had been out of the office the week prior
and had many items to catch up on. FCW stated she recognizes
she should have reported the concerns to Centralized Intake right
away and has learned from this experience.
Documents reviewed:
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case file.
November 25, 2024, social work contact: The FCW
spoke with Caregiver at her home after completing a home
visit with Youth B. Caregiver expressed many frustrations
and concerns with the residential facility. Caregiver stated
she was asked if she wanted to attend Youth B’s psychiatry
3

appointment. Caregiver stated yes but was never provided
the link to join even after following up. Caregiver stated
Youth A is under the impression that vapes/nicotine are not
a big deal because staff at tell Youth A nicotine isn't a big
deal and it isn't something that is watched/monitored.
Caregiver has requested drug screens on several
occasions but have not received them. Caregiver stated the
weekend of November 22nd, Youth A was sent home for a
weekend visit and one of her medications was not sent with
her. Youth A could not sleep the night of the 22nd and was
up all night and day on the 23rd. Caregiver reports Youth A
was in a manic frame of mind. Youth A continued to have
night terrors and not able to sleep well. She is falling asleep
in class and getting "negatives". Caregiver feels this is due
to her medications not being a good mix and not helping.
The FCW let Caregiver know that she was going to go back
to the office and meet with her supervisor to come up with a
plan. Caregiver asked if Youth A could be discharged and
try outpatient services. The FCW stated she would discuss
this with her supervisor. During this conversation, Youth B
mentioned Youth A had told her that a staff member was
providing nicotine vapes to the youth. The FCW let
Caregiver know that this is something that would be
addressed.
December 2, 2024, social work contact: The FCW and
FC Supervisor spoke to Caregiver on the phone regarding
Caregiver’s concerns about the residential facility. The FC
Supervisor explained Caregiver’s concerns are valid and
will be addressed. FC Supervisor stated she would be
sending an email about the concerns.
• MISACWIS Centralized Intake: Confirmation of reported
allegations made on December 2, 2024.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file
allegations were made to FCW on November 25, 2024 regarding
abuse/neglect of Youth A while at the residential facility and she
did not report the concerns to Centralized Intake until the evening
of December 2, 2024.
Conclusion Violation Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
___________12/9/2024_______________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
12/17/2024

Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
